prompt.referenceText: All who have died without a knoweldge of this gospel, who would have received it if they had been permitted to tarry, shall be heirs of the celestial kingdom of God.
prompt.question: What does it mean to have a knowledge of the gospel?
prompt.response:
There are two senses in which we might have a knowledge of the gospel. The first sense is more of a box-ticking exercise that applies to things like the performance of ordinances and believing in the literal name of Christ. The second sense is more about the knowledge of the truth as we seek it, live it, and apply it. 

 The Lord is saying here that the first sense doesn't matter all that much, and that even the second sense is mediated by the principle that where much is given, much is required.

prompt.question: Why do they come in this order? Do we only go through this cycle once?

Every time we learn a new principle, whether or not it's obviously related to the gospel, we go through this process. 

We learn what is good, we change our lives to conform to what is good, we commit to this new life, and continue to work for mastery of this new thing, or to "catch the spirit" of it.

prompt.question: The offices listed here bear very little resemblence to the organization charts of the modern day church. What is this talking about?
prompt.response:
Rather than focus on the names of the offices, focus on the jobs they carry out:

 Apostles bear witness of Christ and direct the church. Prophets are the Lord's mouthpiece. Pastors care for the spiritual and temporal needs of their local congregations. Teachers help us learn and understand the gospel, and Evangelists share the gospel with the world. 

Every function is necessary, and has always been found in God's church, regardless of the actual title.

scryptogram.solution: Now ye may suppose that this is foolishness in me; but behold I say unto you, that by small and simple things are great things brought to pass; and small means in many instances doth confound the wise.

prompt.referenceText: And she brought forth her firstborn son, and wrapped him in swaddling clothes, and laid him in a manger; because there was no room for them in the inn
prompt.question: What can we learn from the symbol of the Christ being laid in a manger?
prompt.response:
Christmas is about new beginnings through Christ. We take the season of the year ending to look again at what we most want to be doing (the "new star" that we're trying to follow), and to take some new action, or recommit ourselves. It might be surprising that these new actions are most impactful when they come from "small and simple" things. Jumping immediately into strenuous activity is usually a recipe for failure. But "small and simple" is exactly how Christ was born. His birth was not clean or pristine. It was as messy as any other birth, and happened in a small, dirty place, surrounded by farm animals. 

So don't be discouraged if your efforts are small, or if they don't seem to match your ambitions. Stay consistent and patient, and they will grow.

prompt.question: How can we know Christ better?
prompt.response: The scryptogram scripture is my favorite answer to this. Be "spiritually minded". This means to see people as God sees them--with compassion, love and appreciation for their potential. It means to live in a way that allows the spirit to be with you--calm, and at peace. scryptogram.solution: And Jesus answered and said unto him, Get thee behind me, Satan: for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve.

prompt.referenceText:
12 And it came to pass that when Moses had said these words, behold, Satan came tempting him, saying: Moses, son of man, worship me.

13 And it came to pass that Moses looked upon Satan and said: Who art thou? For behold, I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten; and where is thy glory, that I should worship thee?
prompt.question: What does it mean to worship something or someone? What's the difference between worshipping God and worshipping Satan?
prompt.response:
God and Satan provide us with opposing patterns for how to accomplish things. God teaches us to forgive, to love, and to lead through persuasive example. Satan teaches us to control, to dominate, and to force at every opportunity. When we think about "worshipping God" we generally think about church and the temple, and when we think about "worshipping Satan", we generally think about occult rituals and things you might see in a horror movie, but worshipping is much more about which methodolgy you choose in your efforts. 

In Norwegian, the verbs for "to pray" and "to ask" are the same word: "å be", and the word for "worship" is closely related: "å tilbe", or to "pray to". So, to worship means to pray to, or to make a request. We request blessings at the hand of Satan when we try to enact his plan, and we request blessings at the hand of God when we act with love and compassion.
